medical: HISTORY: This 75-year-old man was transferred from the nursing home where he lived to the hospital late at night on 4/11 through the Emergency Department in complete urinary obstruction. After catheterization, the patient underwent cystoscopy on 4/13. On 4/14 the patient underwent a transurethral resection of the prostate and was discharged back to the nursing home later that day with voiding improved. Final diagnosis was adenocarcinoma of the prostate. Because of his mental status and general debility, the patient's family declined additional treatment. LABORATORY: None PROCEDURES: Cystoscopy: Blockage of the urethra by a markedly enlarged prostate. Transurethral resection of prostate: 45 grams of tissue were sent to the Pathology Department for analysis. PATHOLOGY: Well differentiated adenocarcinoma, microacinar type, in 1 of 25 chips of prostatic tissue.
layman:
HISTORY: A 75‑year‑old man was taken from his nursing home to the hospital late at night on April 11 because his bladder was completely blocked. After a catheter was inserted, he had a cystoscopy on April 13. On April 14 he had a transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) and was sent back to the nursing home that same day with better urination. The final diagnosis was prostate cancer (adenocarcinoma). Because he has mental and physical weakness, his family chose not to do more treatment.  

LABORATORY: None  

PROCEDURES:  
- Cystoscopy: The urethra was blocked by a very enlarged prostate.  
- TURP: 45 grams of prostate tissue were sent to the Pathology Department.  

PATHOLOGY: The tissue showed a well‑differentiated, microacinar type prostate cancer in 1 of 25 tissue samples.
